message_1: A stream cipher generates a keystream that can be used to encrypt a message. Suppose we have a stream cipher that generates a keystream of 10010110 repeatedly. We want to use this keystream to encrypt a message "HELLO WORLD". Convert the message into binary using ASCII codes and encrypt the message using the stream cipher.
message_2:
First, we need to convert the message "HELLO WORLD" into binary using ASCII codes. Here are the ASCII codes for each character in the message:

H - 72
E - 69
L - 76
L - 76

(space) - 32

Now, we convert these ASCII codes into 8-bit binary:

H - 01001000

L - 01001100
L - 01001100

(space) - 00100000
W - 01010111
O - 01001111
R - 01010010

Now, we will use the stream cipher with the keystream 10010110 to encrypt the message. We do this by performing XOR operation between the binary representation of the message and the keystream:

01001000 (H) XOR 10010110 = 11011110
01000101 (E) XOR 10010110 = 11010011
01001100 (L) XOR 10010110 = 11011010
01001100 (L) XOR 10010110 = 11011010
01001111 (O) XOR 10010110 = 11011001
00100000 (space) XOR 10010110 = 10110110
01010111 (W) XOR 10010110 = 11000001
01001111 (O) XOR 10010110 = 11011001
01010010 (R) XOR 10010110 = 11000100
01001100 (L) XOR 10010110 = 11011010
01000100 (D) XOR 10010110 = 11010010

The encrypted message in binary is:

11011110 11010011 11011010 11011010 11011001 10110110 11000001 11011001 11000100 11011010 11010010

To decrypt the message, we would perform the XOR operation between the encrypted message and the keystream again. This would give us the original binary representation of the message, which can then be converted back to ASCII codes and the original text.
